paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the role of the KCNH2 gene in cardiac arrhythmia, focusing on the molecular mechanisms of inactivation in the hERG channel. Several mutations affecting inactivation are mentioned, but specific variant data is limited.

functional_data.summary: The S620T mutation disrupts a hydrogen bond network, preventing full transition to the collapsed state.

key_quotes: The non-inactivating mutant S620T does not reach a fully collapsed state even at a T620-N629 distance of 5 Å.

functional_data.summary: The G628C/S631C double mutant introduces steric hindrance, inhibiting close approach and stabilizing the conductive state.

key_quotes: In the G628C/S631C double mutant, the steric hindrance introduced by the disulfide bond inhibited such a close approach even further.

functional_data.summary: The N629Q mutation alters the S620–N629 interaction, leading to loss of inactivation.

key_quotes: In contrast to wild-type, which inactivated rapidly, the mutant N629Q hERG channels were devoid of inactivation.

challenges: No specific patient-level data or penetrance statistics were provided.
extraction_metadata.notes: The paper primarily focuses on the molecular mechanisms and functional assays rather than detailed clinical data.
